metadata.case_name: Indian Oxygen Acetylene Co., Private Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 6th October 1956 of Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference I.T. Nos. 40 and 44 of 1956.

Appellant is private limited company incorporated in 1935, head office at Calcutta, manufactures and sells oxygen and acetylene, subsidiary of British Oxygen Co. Ltd., sells to hospitals, nursing homes, industrial concerns for welding, cutting, blasting.
Appellant voluntarily paid bonus equal to two months basic wages for 1952-53 and 1953-54.
Respondents (workmen excluding clerical and clerical staff separately) claimed bonus of 1/3 of total earnings for 1952-53 and 1953-54.
All shares except two or three held by nominee shareholders are held by British Oxygen Co. Ltd.
Appellant prospering, expanding rapidly, capitalised reserves in 1940, 1941, 1942, 1945, 1946, 1947, 1949, major portion of capital from bonus shares.
Good profits for year ending September 30, 1953 and September 30, 1954.
Large gap between actual wages paid and living wage.
Appellant pleaded paying good wages, under formula no additional bonus entitled, voluntary payment more than claimable.

Tribunal rejected appellant's case, directed payment of 1/4 annual basic wages for 1952-53 and 1/3 for 1953-54 less already paid, exclude overtime, dearness and other allowances, subject to two conditions.
Tribunal found not bound by Full Bench formula, rejected rehabilitation claim on social justice considerations.
Without rehabilitation, available surplus Rs. 6,14,830 for 1952-53 and Rs. 12,16,120 for 1953-54 per Tribunal (Ex. TA).
Alternatively, with rehabilitation, no available surplus for both years per Tribunal (Ex. TB).
Previous awards allowed 20% net profits for rehabilitation and expansion (repairs, replacement, modernization, reasonable expansion).
Appellant brought into account one-half general reserve as on Sept 30, 1953 (Rs. 5,51,363) and Sept 30, 1954 (Rs. 3,95,376).
Tribunal impressed by evidence of Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak on rehabilitation, used weighted average method for average life of assets.

legal_issues.text: Whether Industrial Tribunal bound to give effect to Full Bench formula in bonus disputes, including claim for rehabilitation.
Correctness of Tribunal's alternative calculations for available surplus including rehabilitation.
Whether price level of 1956 or bonus years to be considered.
Whether previous rehabilitation amounts brought into account.
Validity of weighted average method for rehabilitation calculations, including exhausted assets and new assets.

petitioner_arguments.text: Paying good wages, under formula no additional bonus entitled, voluntary payment more than claimable.
Tribunal bound to give effect to Full Bench formula, including rehabilitation claim.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Full Bench formula; C.C. Ltd. v. Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Rehabilitation calculations correct using weighted average method by experts Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak, item-wise study.

respondent_arguments.text: Claim bonus 1/3 total earnings due to prosperity, expansion, profits, wage gap.
Tribunal's alternative calculations incorrect: use bonus years price level; previous rehabilitation not accounted; exclude exhausted assets; no double claim for old/new assets.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunals must give effect to Full Bench formula in bonus disputes, including rehabilitation; Tribunal erred in rejecting on social justice.
With rehabilitation per formula, no available surplus (alternative finding).
Price level not confined to bonus years; 1956 level acceptable per A.C.C. case.
Previous rehabilitation (20% for rehab/expansion) to be considered if available, but appellant accounted half general reserve; point not raised before Tribunal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Previous awards included expansion not prior charge

court_reasoning.text: Weighted average method scientifically accurate; include exhausted assets in use; no double claim as depreciation adjustments balance; evidence of experts satisfactory, no material cross-examination defects.

holdings.text: Industrial Tribunals must apply Full Bench formula including rehabilitation in bonus disputes.
Tribunal's alternative calculations correct, no available surplus with rehabilitation.
Weighted average method for rehabilitation valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.C. Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunals must apply Full Bench formula in bonus disputes, how calculations made
Price level not confined to bonus years; previous rehabilitation to be accounted if available unless used

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, Tribunal's award set aside as with rehabilitation per Full Bench formula, no available surplus for bonus in 1952-53 and 1953-54.

key_quotes.text: in dealing with claims for bonus industrial tribunals must give effect to the formula.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the weighted arithmetic mean is obtained as the summation of W x X divided by the summation of W.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Respondents have failed to show that any of the conclusions reached by the tribunal in making its calculations under its alternative finding are wrong.
key_quotes.speaker: court
